bibl.title: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, October 28, 1922

div1.p: Fisher thanks Carter for his public health recommendations. He describes his anti-malaria work and tells of the prevalence of malaria at North and South Carolina sites.

div1.head: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, October 28, 1922
div1.opener:
JAMES A. HAYNE, M. D.
Secretary and State Health Officer
L. M. FISHER
Associate Sanitary Engineer
U. S. Public Health Service
In Charge Malaria Co-operative Work
State Board of Health
of South Carolina
DIVISION MALARIA CO-OPERATIVE WORK
Columbia Oct. 28, 1922.
Dr. H. R. Carter
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I wish to thank you for a copy of the Recommendations
prepared by LePrince and Griffiths for the governing of
the Alabama Power Company on the Coosa River. I will
examine this over Sunday and return it to you on Monday.

I also received your letters addressed to me at Raleigh
and Marion, and appreciate your writing to me and your
discussion of the conditions at both ponds.

At Marion I found full grown larvae and pupae in the pond
near the head of Mill Creek on the Padey Creek section,
and also in some other coves; one I recall, at the foot
of a slope on which Lawyer Mull of Morganton built a
fish lodge. This examination was made after a spell of
rainy weather and very probably the larvae were washed
in from the streams. On one of the coves on Mill Creek
I found small larvae, not over one-third grown, which it
seems to me must have developed in the pond because if
they had been carried into the pond from streams I should
think they would have drowned. I found these fairly
numerous, picking up from 0 to 4 in each dip for 15 or
20 dips, with about 75 percent of the dips containing
larvae. I found them among flotage along the bank in
places where there was very little wave action. Under-
neath the flotage I observed small sun fish and a small
black fish, about the size of a full grown Gambusia, but
much quicker and very shy. Schools of perch in the deep-
er water kept the small fish close to the shore and re-
peatedly darted among them.

In one of the pools near Yancey's bridge, about three-
quarters of a mile east of the bridge, I found a few full
-2-
grown larvae that developed into punctipennis. This pool
had neither in-flow or outflow of water. A little further
east among some dead undergrowth standing in the waters
edge and among small pieces of drift I found full-grown
larvae and pupae which I think were washed in from the
stream. I found no small larvae among them.

The weather was getting very cool; the temperature of the
water had fallen to 65 degrees. We had had several frosts.

At Badin I found breeding in the pond at places where it
could not reasonably be expected to have had its origin in
streams and found small larvae and pupae. I found larvae
in flotage at the bank and attached to floating pieces of
bark and logs away from the shore. The pond was drawn
down about 9 feet, but was rising, having come up about
6 feet in the last two weeks. The Plant is running and is
taking on new men. Four pot rooms were in operation and
the fifth was to be placed in operation soon.

Mr. Nash, who is directly in charge of the control work
was with me.

My principal criticism at Badin, I thin, is that the control
measures recommended to the Company, which they are trying
to carry out, have not been carried out sufficiently fully
to be a hundred percent effective. Just how effective they
are it is hard to state. All of the families I visited
within flight distance of the area where control measures
were employed, claim to have had malaria this year or last.
The Company screened one of its houses on Glady Fork, but
used fourteen mesh wire and did not screen the chimney.
They oiled log jams at intervals of 16 to 25 days. This
interval I think was too long. They introduced between
15,000 and 18,000 top minnows this summer. This I think is
a mere drop in the bucket compared with what is required for
the pond. Undoubtedly it is a step along the right direction.

Dr. Moore was employed by the Company this summer to work
among the people at the upper end of the pond in order to
elliminate malaria. He visited them several times a week
and gave intrevenes injections of quinine in 7 1/2 to 10 grain
doses, at intervals of two or three days. He told me of
one person who had not had any chills, but the doctor thot
he looked as tho he had malaria and advised him to take the
doctor's treatment. After taking two or three shots he de-
veloped chills. The doctor made, therefore, the same
degree of success of Mr. Nash with his fish hatchery. He
had to move it to a new location because everybody in a
house a few hundred feet from the hatchery came down with
chills!

Dr. Moore made blood examination of fifty-three people and
got twenty-seven positive blood smears and twenty-six
negative. The positive ones were invariably obtained from
persons who had had chills recently; that is, within a
month or two of the time the blood was taken.

The Company shows a willingness to do whatever is reasonable.
Dr. Rankin wants the Service to formulate regulations which
power companies can be asked to follow. Dr. Moore received
very poor cooperation from some of the people among whom
he was trying to work.

closer.signed:
L. M. Fisher
Associate Sanitary Engineer
In Charge Mal. Cont. Work in S. C.
